## **17.4Â Plotting Calendar Heatmap**

In this section, you will learn how to plot a calender heatmap programmatically by using ggplot2 package.

By the end of this section, you will be able to:

-   plot a calender heatmap by using ggplot2 functions and extension,

-   to write function using R programming,

-   to derive specific date and time related field by using base R and lubridate packages

-   to perform data preparation task by using tidyr and dplyr packages.

### **17.4.1Â The Data**

For the purpose of this hands-on exercise,Â *eventlog.csv*Â file will be used. This data file consists of 199,999 rows of time-series cyber attack records by country.

### **17.4.2Â Importing the data**

First, you will use the code chunk below to importÂ *eventlog.csv*Â file into R environment and called the data frame asÂ *attacks*.

```{r}
attacks <- read_csv("/Users/geloliu/Gelo-608/ISSS608/Hands-on Exercises/Hands-on Ex 07/data/Hands-on_Ex07/eventlog.csv")
```

### **17.4.3Â Examining the data structure**

It is always a good practice to examine the imported data frame before further analysis is performed.

For example,Â *kable()*Â can be used to review the structure of the imported data frame.

```{r}
kable(head(attacks))
```

There are three columns, namelyÂ *timestamp*,Â *source_country*Â andÂ *tz*.

-   *timestamp*Â field stores date-time values in POSIXct format.

-   *source_country*Â field stores the source of the attack. It is inÂ *ISO 3166-1 alpha-2*Â country code.

-   *tz*Â field stores time zone of the source IP address.

### **17.4.4Â Data Preparation**

Step 1: DerivingÂ *weekday*Â andÂ *hour of day*Â fields

Before we can plot the calender heatmap, two new fields namelyÂ *wkday*Â andÂ *hour*Â need to be derived. In this step, we will write a function to perform the task.

```{r}
make_hr_wkday <- function(ts, sc, tz) {
  real_times <- ymd_hms(ts, 
                        tz = tz[1], 
                        quiet = TRUE)
  dt <- data.table(source_country = sc,
                   wkday = weekdays(real_times),
                   hour = hour(real_times))
  return(dt)
  }
```

+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **ðŸ“’ Note**                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
+=======================================================================================================================================================================================================================+
| -   [`ymd_hms()`](https://lubridate.tidyverse.org/reference/ymd_hms.html)Â andÂ [`hour()`](https://lubridate.tidyverse.org/reference/hour.html)Â are fromÂ [**lubridate**](https://lubridate.tidyverse.org/)Â package, and |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| -   [`weekdays()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/weekdays)Â is aÂ **base**Â R function.                                                                                             |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

Step 2: Deriving the attacks tibble data frame

```{r}
wkday_levels <- c('Saturday', 'Friday', 
                  'Thursday', 'Wednesday', 
                  'Tuesday', 'Monday', 
                  'Sunday')

attacks <- attacks %>%
  group_by(tz) %>%
  do(make_hr_wkday(.$timestamp, 
                   .$source_country, 
                   .$tz)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(wkday = factor(
    wkday, levels = wkday_levels),
    hour  = factor(
      hour, levels = 0:23))
```

| **ðŸ“’ Note** |
|----|
| Beside extracting the necessary data intoÂ *attacks*Â data frame,Â `mutate()`Â ofÂ **dplyr**package is used to convertÂ *wkday*Â andÂ *hour*Â fields intoÂ **factor**Â so theyâ€™ll be ordered when plotting |

Table below shows the tidy tibble table after processing.

```{r}
kable(head(attacks))
```

### **17.4.5Â Building the Calendar Heatmaps**

```{r}
grouped <- attacks %>% 
  count(wkday, hour) %>% 
  ungroup() %>%
  na.omit()

ggplot(grouped, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
coord_equal() +
scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
labs(x = NULL, 
     y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks by weekday and time of day") +
theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
      plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
      legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
      legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )
```

### **17.4.6Â Building Multiple Calendar Heatmaps**

**Challenge:**Â Building multiple heatmaps for the top four countries with the highest number of attacks.

### **17.4.7Â Plotting Multiple Calendar Heatmaps**

Step 1: Deriving attack by country object

In order to identify the top 4 countries with the highest number of attacks, you are required to do the followings:

-   count the number of attacks by country,

-   calculate the percent of attackes by country, and

-   save the results in a tibble data frame.

```{r}
attacks_by_country <- count(
  attacks, source_country) %>%
  mutate(percent = percent(n/sum(n))) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))
```

Step 2: Preparing the tidy data frame

In this step, you are required to extract the attack records of the top 4 countries fromÂ *attacks*Â data frame and save the data in a new tibble data frame (i.e.Â *top4_attacks*).

```{r}
top4 <- attacks_by_country$source_country[1:4]
top4_attacks <- attacks %>%
  filter(source_country %in% top4) %>%
  count(source_country, wkday, hour) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(source_country = factor(
    source_country, levels = top4)) %>%
  na.omit()
```

### **17.4.8Â Plotting Multiple Calendar Heatmaps**

Step 3: Plotting the Multiple Calender Heatmap by using ggplot2 package.

```{r}
ggplot(top4_attacks, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
  geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
  coord_equal() +
  scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
  facet_wrap(~source_country, ncol = 2) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks on top 4 countries by weekday and time of day") +
  theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 7),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )
```

## **17.5Â Plotting Cycle Plot**

In this section, you will learn how to plot a cycle plot showing the time-series patterns and trend of visitor arrivals from Vietnam programmatically by using ggplot2 functions.

### **17.5.1Â Step 1: Data Import**

For the purpose of this hands-on exercise,Â *arrivals_by_air.xlsx*Â will be used.

The code chunk below importsÂ *arrivals_by_air.xlsx*Â by usingÂ `read_excel()`Â ofÂ **readxl**Â package and save it as a tibble data frame calledÂ *air*.

```{r}
air <- read_excel("/Users/geloliu/Gelo-608/ISSS608/Hands-on Exercises/Hands-on Ex 07/data/Hands-on_Ex07/arrivals_by_air.xlsx")
```

### **17.5.2Â Step 2: Deriving month and year fields**

Next, two new fields calledÂ *month*Â andÂ *year*Â are derived fromÂ *Month-Year*Â field.

```{r}
air$month <- factor(month(air$`Month-Year`), 
                    levels=1:12, 
                    labels=month.abb, 
                    ordered=TRUE) 
air$year <- year(ymd(air$`Month-Year`))
```

### **17.5.3Â Step 4: Extracting the target country**

Next, the code chunk below is use to extract data for the target country (i.e.Â Vietnam)

```{r}
Vietnam <- air %>% 
  select(`Vietnam`, 
         month, 
         year) %>%
  filter(year >= 2010)
```

### **17.5.4Â Step 5: Computing year average arrivals by month**

The code chunk below usesÂ `group_by()`Â andÂ `summarise()`Â ofÂ **dplyr**Â to compute year average arrivals by month.

```{r}
hline.data <- Vietnam %>% 
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(avgvalue = mean(`Vietnam`))
```

### **17.5.5Â Srep 6: Plotting the cycle plot**

The code chunk below is used to plot the cycle plot as shown in Slide 12/23.

```{r}
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=Vietnam,
            aes(x=year, 
                y=`Vietnam`, 
                group=month), 
            colour="black") +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept=avgvalue), 
             data=hline.data, 
             linetype=6, 
             colour="red", 
             size=0.5) + 
  facet_grid(~month) +
  labs(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
       title = "Visitor arrivals from Vietnam by air, Jan 2010-Dec 2019") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("No. of Visitors") +
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica")
```

## **17.6Â Plotting Slopegraph**

In this section you will learn how to plot aÂ [slopegraph](https://www.storytellingwithdata.com/blog/2020/7/27/what-is-a-slopegraph)Â by using R.

Before getting start, make sure thatÂ **CGPfunctions**Â has been installed and loaded onto R environment. Then, refer toÂ [Using newggslopegraph](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/CGPfunctions/vignettes/Using-newggslopegraph.html)Â to learn more about the function. Lastly, read more aboutÂ `newggslopegraph()`Â and its arguments by referring to thisÂ [link](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/CGPfunctions/versions/0.6.3/topics/newggslopegraph).

### **17.6.1Â Step 1: Data Import**

Import the rice data set into R environment by using the code chunk below.

```{r}
rice <- read_csv("/Users/geloliu/Gelo-608/ISSS608/Hands-on Exercises/Hands-on Ex 07/data/Hands-on_Ex07/rice.csv")
```

### **17.6.2Â Step 2: Plotting the slopegraph**

Next, code chunk below will be used to plot a basic slopegraph as shown below.

```{r}
rice %>% 
  mutate(Year = factor(Year)) %>%
  filter(Year %in% c(1961, 1980)) %>%
  newggslopegraph(Year, Yield, Country,
                Title = "Rice Yield of Top 11 Asian Counties",
                SubTitle = "1961-1980",
                Caption = "Prepared by: Dr. Kam Tin Seong")
```

| **ðŸ’¡ Thing to learn from the code chunk above** |
|----|
| For effective data visualisation design,Â `factor()`Â is used convert the value type ofÂ *Year*field from numeric to factor. |
